City of Faribault

Water Treatment Plant

Risk Management Program

Executive Summary







1.0  Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies



The City of Faribault has a long-standing commitment to operating our facilities in a manner that is safe for our employees, the public, and the environment.  A primary aspect of this commitment is the City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant to help ensure the safe operation of the water chlorination process.  Our commitment is also demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process, as well as, extensive training of our operating personnel. 



In the event of an accidental release, the City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant has procedures that are designed to control and contain the release in a manner that will be safe for our employees and will help prevent injury to the public and the environment.  The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant's emergency response personnel receive thorough training in handling accidental releases.  An emergency response coordinator has been assigned to oversee response activities and to coordinate response efforts with local emergency agencies.  Communications with the Local Emergency Management Agency have been ongoing throughout the preparation of this plan and policies.



In order to effectively implement these policies, the City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant established a management system headed by the Water Quality Supervisor to ensure the proper implementation and effectiveness of our Risk Management Program.





2.0  City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant and Regulated Substances



The City of Faribault, Minnesota serves more than 21,100 customers with an average demand of 3.1 MGD and a peak water demand of 7.0 MGD.  The City obtains all its water supply from five wells and it is pumped to a one million gallon low-level reservoir.  The raw water entering

the reservoir passes through a chemical feed manhole where chemicals are added to the water.  Chemicals added include chlorine gas, ammonia, hydrofluosilicic acid and polyphosphate.  All chemicals are housed in the high service pump building.  Water from the low level reservoir is pumped into the distribution system by four (4) high service pumps.

The Facility and Regulated Substances



This is a local government owned and operated facility for the production of potable water for the City of Faribault. The only reportable regulated substance for the RMP plan is chlorine. No more than two tons of chlorine is stored at this facility in ton cylinders. Normally only one cylinder is online at one time. The online tanks are on isolated regulators that reduce the chlorine pressure to 26.6 PSI. Chlorine feed equipment supplies a vacuum to the tanks allowing the release of chlorine to the feeders. The tanks are shut off with a manual valve and all residual chlorine is evacuated from the lines when the plant is off. No flammable substances or other restricted items are stored in the chlorine tank rooms. The room has a chlorine detector connected to an alarm panel, and autodialer. All unacknowledged alarms initiate the autodialer, which calls all on duty and off duty personnel till acknowledged. If the alarm is acknowledged and the condition exists after an hour it again starts calling operators out. All alarms and autodialers are on back up battery power supply.



Process Description: Chlorination

Program Level: 3

Regulated Substance: Chlorine







3.0  Hazard Assessment Results



The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant performed an offsite consequence analysis to estimate the potential impacts of accidental releases of the Chlorine from our process. The regulated substance was evaluated for a possible worse-case release scenario and alternative release scenario.  It is important to understand that the City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant has invested extensive

resources to prevent releases, and the potential for a worse-case release is extremely small.  The alternative release scenario represents a more realistic potential for occurrence and is based on historical data from our process or other similar processes.  By identifying these potential releases, the City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant has developed an extensive program to prevent such an occurrence.  This program is discussed in detail in the Prevention Program section of this plan.

The primary objective of performing the offsite consequence analysis is to determine the distance at which certain effects might occur to the public and/or the environment as a result of an accidental release.  This point is called the endpoint distance.  At distances less than the endpoint distance, the effects would be greater; at distances farther than the endpoint, the effects would be less.



3.1  Hazard Assessment - Toxic Substances



The worst-case scenario (WCS) associated with Regulated Toxic Substances is a failure of a full, one ton (2000 lb) cylinder of liquid chlorine.  A toxic cloud formed by the evaporating chlorine would reach offsite endpoints and public receptors.



An alternative release scenario (ARS) for chlorine releases is a release from a vessel leak.  The modeled release lasted for 30 minutes before it is stopped.  A toxic cloud formed by the evaporating chlorine would reach offsite endpoints and public receptors.





4.0  Accidental Release Prevention Program - Program 3



The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant Chlorination Process is covered by the OSHA Process Safety Management standard.  The requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management standard are nearly identical to the RMP Rule Program 3 Prevention Program requirements.  The Chlorination Process Prevention Program consists of the following elements.



4.1  Process Safety Information



The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant maintains a variety of technical documents that help

ensure the safe operation of our processes.  These documents address:



* physical properties of hazardous substances handled,

* chemical properties and associated hazards of those substances,

* operating parameters and limitation(s) of the process equipment,

* design basis and configuration of the equipment, and

* specific chemical inventories.

 

The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant ensures that the process safety information is available to all City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant employees, the Local Emergency Management Agency, and the local fire department.  



Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs).  This information is supplemented by other technical information specific for these chemicals.  Continuous attention is given to revisions and updates on the hazards of chlorine and other chemicals used in our process.  Information regarding toxicity, environmental impacts, corrosion concerns, inadvertent mixing hazards, and other safety and health concerns are addressed and communicated to the appropriate parties.



The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes:

 

* materials of construction,

* design pressures,

* temperature ratings,

* electrical ratings,

* flow limits,

* block flow diagrams,

* consequences of deviation from operating limits,

* safety systems,

* applicable design codes and standards,

* process chemistry, and

* design basis for relief and ventilation systems.



Many of the operating parameters are included in the operating procedures to aid in the safe and proper operation of the process.  These documents are used to:



* train employees,

* perform Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs), and

* help maintain the equipment.



All the above mentioned informat

ion, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provide a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the Chlorination Process are not compromised.



4.2  Process Hazard Analysis



The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant performed and will periodically update process hazard analyses (PHAs) of the Chlorination Process to help identify process hazards and generate recommendations that might improve the safe operation of the process.  Within this program, the Chlorination Process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.

To perform the PHAs, City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant primarily uses the "What-if/Checklist" technique.  The PHAs are conducted using a team of people with experience in engineering and Chlorination Process operation and a leader with experience in process hazard analysis techniques. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and/or mitigation measures, when appropriate.  The team then prepares a written report describing the results of the analysis, including a list of recommendations ranked according to relative risk ratings assigned by the team.  Responsibility to resolve the recommendations is assigned to the EHS Committee and is tracked through completion.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the Chlorination Process is no longer in operation.  The results and findings of these updates are docum

ented and retained.  The team findings are forwarded to the EHS Committee for consideration, and the final resolution of the findings is documented and retained.



4.3  Operating Procedures



City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant engineers, operators, and management work together to develop and maintain written operating procedures to define how tasks related to the Chlorination Process operation should be safely performed.  These written procedures address various modes of process operations, such as:



* normal startup,

* normal operations,

* temporary operations,

* emergency shutdown,

* normal shutdown, and

* initial startup of a new process.

 



 The written operating procedures include:

 

* steps for safely conducting process tasks,

* applicable process safety information, such as safe operating limits and consequences of process deviations, and

* safety and health considerations, such as chemical hazards, personal protective equipment requirements, and action(s) to take in the event of an exposure to a hazardous substance.



4.4  Training



The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant trains workers to safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks.  The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant training program includes both initial and refresher training that covers:



* a general overview of the Chlorination Process,

* the properties and hazards of the substances in the process, and

* a detailed review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices.



In addition to the above mentioned classroom training, each operator is required to work for a period of time with an experienced operator until clear understanding of the operating procedures is demonstrated.  Refresher training is conducted annually as part of the City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant's ongoing safety training effort.



4.5  Mechanical Integrity



The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant maintains the mechanical integrity of Chlorination Process eq

uipment to help prevent failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment.  The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant mechanical integrity program includes:



* an inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage before the equipment fails,

* a quality assurance program to help ensure that the new and replacement equipment meet the design standards required for service in our process,

* procedures for safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, hot work, confined space entry and line or equipment opening,

* training of maintenance personnel, and

* documentation of maintenance activities.





4.6  Management of Change



The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant has a comprehensive program to manage changes to processes.  Under this program, all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, and procedures for the Chlorination Process must be evaluated and approved to help ensure the change does not negatively affect safe operations.  Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, and procedures are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided with any necessary training related to the change.





4.7  Pre-startup Review



The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant performs a safety review of all new or modified processes prior to their being placed into service to ensure that these processes have been prepared to operate safely.  This review is designed to confirm:



* construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications,

* adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place,

* employee training has been completed, and

* for covered processes, a PHA has been performed for new processes

and management of change requirements have been completed for modified processes.

 

A pre-startup review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness.  The review involves field verification of the construction elements and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

 



4.8  Compliance Audit

 

The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant conducts periodic audits of the Chlorination Process to ensure the City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant Prevention Program has been effectively implemented and addresses the safety issues of our operations.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years by a team of hourly and management personnel who are knowledgeable of the RMP Rule and the Chlorination Process.  The team evaluates the City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant Prevention Program and other aspects of the City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant Risk Management Program.  The results of the audit are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the Prevention Program are implemented.  The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant maintains records of at least the last two audits conducted.

 



4.9  Incident Investigation

 

The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.

 



4.10  Employee Participation

 

The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant developed a written employee participation program for the Chlorination Process and other aspects of o

ur operations to ensure that the safety concerns are addressed.  The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant encourages the active participation of our employees in the Prevention Program for all processes and tasks at our facility.  Employees are consulted on and informed of all aspects of the City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant Risk Management Plan (RMP) and participate on PHA and Compliance Audit teams.

 



4.11  Hot Work Permits

 

The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant established a Safe Work Permit program to control spark or flame producing activities that could result in fires or explosions in the processes at our facility.  The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant utilizes a Safe Work Permit form designed after the OSHA fire prevention and protection requirements found in 29 CFR 1910.252(a).  Personnel who are to perform the Hot Work are required to complete the form which is reviewed by the area supervisor.  The form must be approved before work can proceed.  Training in the use of the Safe Work Permit form is provided to all affected personnel.

 



4.12  Contractors

 

The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant established a program to help ensure that contractors who are used to supplement the workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction conduct their work in a safe manner.  Under the program, the record of all contractors is reviewed to ensure that City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant hires contractors who can safely perform work on or near covered process equipment.  Our program ensures that contractors:

 

* perform their work in a safe manner,

* have the appropriate knowledge and skills,

* are aware of the hazards in the workplace,

* understand what to do in the event of an emergency,

* understand and follow the City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant's safety rules, and

* inform City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant personnel of any hazards identified during their work.

 

Program efforts are accom

plished by providing contractors with:

 

* a process overview,

* information about safety and health hazards,

* emergency response plan requirements, and

* safe work practices prior to beginning work.

 



5.0  Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

 

Industry standards are followed at the City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant to help ensure safe handling of chlorine.  The vendor supplies chlorine via a Department of Transportation (DOT) approved truck and in DOT approved 1 ton cylinders.  The chlorination process equipment is designed and constructed with state-of-the-art materials and technology utilizing the standards and guidelines of the Chlorine Institute, American Water Works Association, ASME, ANSI, and other applicable codes.  Workers who perform operations involving chlorine receive training emphasizing safe handling procedures according to the guidelines required by the City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant. 





6.0  Emergency Response Programs

 

The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant has prepared a written emergency action plan that complies with the RMP Rule, other federal standards and industry guidelines.  This plan has been communicated to the Local Emergency Management Agency and local fire department.  The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant periodically conducts emergency drills to test our emergency plan and coordinate these drills with the local fire department.





7.0  Five Year Accident History



There has been no accidents or incidents that resulted in injuries to employee, the public, or the environment at The City of Faribault Water Treatment Plant in the past five years.
